Introduction

Blepharitis is an ophthalmologic condition characterized by inflammation and irritation at the eyelid margins.  It is typically a chronic disorder with symptoms that wax and wane over time.  Patients experience swelling, itching, and crusting of both eyelids and may have burning or a foreign body sensation in the eye.  Blepharitis is mainly a clinical diagnosis, and eyelid hygiene is the mainstay of treatment.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Blepharitis is more common in adults than in children, and risk increases with advancing age.  It can be classified as either anterior, involving the base of the eyelashes, or posterior, involving the inner aspect of the eyelid, with considerable overlap in many cases.



The etiology of blepharitis is multifactorial and the exact pathophysiological mechanisms are not completely understood.  However, several conditions contribute to an increased risk of blepharitis:



  • Systemic inflammatory skin conditions (eg, seborrheic dermatitis, rosacea, eczema) associated with chronic irritation and inflammation of the face, scalp, and eyelid
  • Bacterial colonization (typically Staphylococcus), which can lead to eyelid irritation and infection
  • Overpopulation of Demodex mites, parasites that are part of normal eyelid flora in most people; however, increased numbers may lead to an inflammatory reaction
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction, in which these eye-lubricating glands are blocked by excess oil or debris, leading to an abnormal tear film that induces inflammation along the inner aspect of the eyelid
  • Contact irritants (eg, contact lenses, cosmetics), which may cause localized allergic response after direct exposure
  • Poor eyelid hygiene, which can promote inflammation resulting from excess oil and skin flaking

Clinical presentation



Blepharitis typically involves both eyes.  Symptoms include:



  • Itching and burning of the eyelids
  • Redness and swelling of the eyelid margins
  • Scaling or flaking of the eyelid skin
  • Discharge, crusting, or matting along the eyelashes (worst upon waking)
  • Foreign body sensation
  • Excessive tearing
  • Loss or misdirection of eyelashes

Diagnosis



Blepharitis is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on characteristic signs and symptoms.  Key steps during the examination include:



  • Inspection of the eyelid margins for characteristic signs of inflammation, including edema, erythema and crusting
  • Assessment of tear film quality, which may be abnormal due to meibomian gland dysfunction (examination is under a slit lamp, using fluorescein stain to evaluate for dry spots or breaks in the film)
  • Evaluation for engorged, obstructed meibomian glands that appear as bumps on the inner surface of the eyelid

Differential diagnosis



  • Hordeolum (ie, stye) (
    image 1
    ):  an acute localized inflammatory lesion of the eyelid caused by obstruction of a meibomian gland.  It typically presents as a discrete, focally tender, erythematous nodule, rather than diffuse inflammation, erythema, and crusting of the entire eyelid margin.
  • Chalazion (
    image 2
    ):  a chronic, non-infectious inflammatory nodule resulting from obstruction of the meibomian gland.  It presents as a painless, firm, solitary nodule on the eyelid margin.  It has no erythema, crusting, and relapsing episodes.
  • Conjunctivitis (
    image 3
    ):  an acute inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin membrane that covers the sclera and inner eyelid.  It may be bacterial, viral, or allergic in nature.  Conjunctivitis presents with redness and irritation of the eye with discharge, but the eyelid margins are typically not involved.
  • Preseptal cellulitis:  a bacterial infection of the eyelids and periorbital soft tissues that presents with erythema and edema of the affected area.  It can appear similar to blepharitis but is usually unilateral and involves the entire eyelid (not just the margin).

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



Laboratory tests are not routinely necessary for the diagnosis of blepharitis.  However, in cases of suspected secondary infection or possible malignancy, additional tests such as bacterial culture or skin biopsy may be indicated.



Imaging studies are generally not required when evaluating blepharitis, unless there is suspicion for an acute infection extending into the posterior orbit (ie, orbital cellulitis).  Computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may be used to assess the extent of infection.

Management



Blepharitis tends to be a recurrent condition without a definitive cure.  Management involves routine, long-term interventions to alleviate acute symptoms and prevent future exacerbations:



  • Eyelid hygiene with daily warm compresses and gentle lid scrubs to remove debris and crusts; meibomian gland massage may also improve symptoms
  • Lubricating eye drops or ointments, which can alleviate symptoms of dry eye that may further increase inflammatory response
  • Avoidance of triggers such as eye makeup and other irritants


Patients with severe or continuing symptoms should be administered topical antibiotics (eg, bacitracin).  Oral antibiotics (eg, doxycycline) can be used in severe cases unresponsive to topical therapy and topical corticosteroids may be considered for refractory cases.  In addition, treatment of underlying conditions (eg, seborrheic dermatitis, rosacea, Demodex infestation) may help improve blepharitis symptoms.

Prognosis



Blepharitis is typically a chronic, relapsing condition, but with appropriate treatment and eyelid hygiene most patients experience improvement in symptoms and a reduced frequency of exacerbations.



Complications are uncommon but can include corneal abrasions/erosions from an inflamed eyelid rubbing against the cornea.  Dry eye disease is another complication of blepharitis, likely related to meibomian gland dysfunction.

Summary
